text: The regulation of HIV by retinoic acid correlates with cellular expression of the retinoic acid receptors .
OBJECTIVES : To analyze the effect of retinoic acids ( RA ) on HIV-1 expression and correlate this effect with expression levels of RA receptors ( RARs ) in T-lymphoid and monocytoid cell lines .
DESIGN AND METHODS : The effect of all-trans and 9-cis RA on HIV-1 production in T-lymphoid ( H9 , CEM ) and monocytoid ( U937 , THP-1 ) cell lines was measured during acute and chronic infection .

The expression levels of human <extra_id_0> RAR alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> hRAR alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , receptor for all-trans RA ) and the human <extra_id_0> retinoid-X receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> hRXR alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> receptor for 9-cis RA ) were determined by Northern blot analysis .

text: RESULTS : Both all-trans and 9-cis RA inhibited virus replication in HIV-1 IIIB-infected monocytoid cells , in the presence and absence of the co-stimulatory agent phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) .
The retinoids had weak or no stimulatory effects on HIV production by T-cell lines .
HIV production by PMA - stimulated T-cell lines was inhibited by these retinoids .
The 9-cis RA was generally more effective than all-trans RA in inhibiting HIV production and in combination generally more effective than the single agents alone .
Human RAR alpha was expressed in H9 , U937 and THP-1 cells , but almost undetectable in CEM cells .
Human <extra_id_0> RXR alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was significantly expressed in U937 and THP-1 cells , weakly expressed in H9 cells and not detectable in CEM cells .

text: After stimulation by PMA , <extra_id_0> RXR alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression increased in H9 and U937 cells but not in CEM cells .

text: CONCLUSION : The effect of RA on HIV-1 expression was cell-type - dependent and partially correlated with cellular expression of RARs .
Endogenous or exogenously administered RA may have a significant role in HIV regulation .
